Speaker purports Dukakis talk,
instead praises Jackson plans
by Michael McCully
The audience at the Glass Pavilion heard of a new
political wave sweeping the nation. It heard that the
progressive populism of the Rev. Jesse Jackson is
apparently hotter than Nintendo at Christmas.
These phenomena, as well as a presentation of
Jackson's platform, were addressed by Vincente
Navarro Sunday in a lecture sponsored by the Office of the Chaplain.
Navarro served as a Jackson policy advisor for
the 1988 Presidential campaign, was a member of
the 1988 Democratic Platform Committee, and was
a Maryland delegate to the Democratic Convention
in Atlanta. He now serves on the Maryland Rainbow Coalition Steering Committee and is Professor
of Health and Public Policy at the School of Hygiene
and Public Health.
The lecture had been advertised as a talk on why
Governor Michael Dukakis(D-Mass.) and Senator
Lloyd Bentsen(D-Texas) lost their run for the White
House. Though the lecture was titled "Why
Dukakis Lost the Election," Navarro touched on
this subject only briefly in his talk.
He spent the bulk of his lecture endorsing what
he called "the most progressive Democratic platform since the New Deal of the Thirties, "crediting
Jackson's campaign as the impetus behind what he
saw as the Democratic Party's move to the left.

Navarro faulted Dukakis and Bentsen's movement
away from Jackson's policies and the platform put
forth by the Democrats in Atlanta as reasons for the
ticket's sharp decline in the polls last fall and its
eventual defeat. Navarro contended that only when
Dukakis "rediscovered his populist roots" did he
regain some momentum in the campaign. But, alas,
that discovery came too late.
According to Navarro, Dukakis's apparent move
to the political right cost him the election. Navarro
provided statistics and polls to support his contention that the majority of Americans support an expansion of government support of social programs.
If this working class group could be mobilized into
a voting coalition, he said, then its role in the next
Presidential election would indeed be powerful.
Navarro advised the Democratic Party to follow
Jackson's lead and target the blue-collar vote with
consistent populist rhetoric.
The question-and-answer period following the
lecture was for all intents and purposes a Jesse
Jackson rally. One audience member would stand
up and praise Jackson. Others would then voice their
agreement. Before the lecture broke up, Navarro
left a parting message: Jackson, he said, is the future
of the Democratic Party, and if the Democrats wish
to recapture the White House, they should follow
his lead to the left.

Hopkins has decided to
phase out and close by
December 31, 1991 the
Chesapeake Bay institute, an
estuarine and oceanographic

Maryland, and at the
Homewood campus in
Baltimore.

would be too costly to, main-

tain the institute as a first-rank

the decision to close the
institute.

prepared late last year by the

DBI to diminish from

1993. CBI's researchers raise

in research contracts and an

additional $400,000 in indirect
cost recoveries. However, that
supports only about eighty
percent of the institute's $2.8
million budget.
The decision will affect fifteen researchers and twentyfive senior and support staff
personnel. University officials
said they expect the nearly
three years of lead time to

find positions elsewhere. They
said staff members will be encouraged to apply for other
positions
within
the
University.

made about the disposition of
CBI's physical plant at Shady
Side. A research group in
aquatic ecology from the
University Applied Physics
Laboratory operates out of
CBI's quarters at Shady Side
and its future has not been
determined.
University Provost John V.
Lombardi, who is charged by
the Board of Trustees with implementing the Five-Year
Plan, said he regards the decision to close CBI as keeping
with the Hopkins tradition to

choose areas of research
carefully and to pursue them
only as long as resources allow
excellence to be maintained.
Lombardi stressed that the
University will continue to
have a strong commitment to
environmental research. He
said that more than fifty faculty members in four divisions
of the University are working
on more than $20 million in
environmental projects.

To the Editors:
There has been much talk about
the five-year financial plan which
is currently under consideration
by the administration. The fiveyear plan is a possible solution to
the financial difficulties being experienced by the School of Arts
and Sciences. According to the
most recent draft of the five-year
plan, by the year 1993 the School
of Arts and Sciences will show a
chronic deficit. The plan seeks to
avoid this disaster by reformatting many of the departments
within the School of Arts and
Sciences.
Among the measures to be implemented is the selection of the
"key disciplines" within the
School of Arts and Sciences and
the phasing out of the rest. In addition, the draft calls for cutting
faculty by ten percent, while increasing undergraduate enrollment by 230 students. These
measures would obviously lead to
an increased student to faculty
ratio, which is generally seen as
a lowering of standards. Furthermore, there is a planned increase
in tuition. While next year's
freshmen would feel the brunt of
the increase, all classes would be
affected.
The question here is what
quality of education and at what
price. These issues concern all of

us who have decided to obtain our
education at Hopkins. As such
there will be a question and
answer session on the Five-Year
Plan on Tuesday, Febuary 21 at
5:00 p.m. in the Garrett Room of
the MSE Library. The time will
be posted on the bulletin boards.

What's more frightening than
Alien, more insidious than a
bunch of Body Snatchers, and
makes the Blob seem as threatening as a bowl of Cream of Wheat?
It's Audrey II, that mean green
mother from outerspace, and it's
coming to the Arellano Theater
this weekend in the Barnstormer's production of Little
Shop of Horrors.
If you caught the 1986 film version of the musical, you're in for
a bit of a surprise. Written by the
award-winning team of Howard
Ashman and Alan Menken, this
off-off Broadway hit has a
number of musical numbers that
weren't included in the movie, as
well as the original ending which
is a far cry from the washed-out
rendition that made it to the
screen.
Ashman wrote in the forward
to the script that Little Shop tries
to spoof a bit of everything:
"science fiction, B-movies,
musical comedy, and even the
Faust legend." The play satirizes
the rise of a meek Skid Row
florist clerk, Seymore Krelbom,
as an unearthly botanical

discovery delivers everything he
has ever hoped for—fame, fortune, respect, love—as well as
some things he didn't—terror,
greed, and the occasional
bloodshed.
Under the direction of Jill
Ehnenn, the cast is headed by Jim
Stofan as Seymore, Kathy Kennedy as Audrey, the love interest,
Jason Katz as Mushnik, the
florist, Jeremy Golub as the Dentist, and Andy Angelino as the
voice of Audrey II. In terms of
its enormous complexity, size,
and expense, the Little Shop production may be the most ambitious project undertaken in the
Barnstormer's eighty-two year
history. It is certainly among the
most professional.
The show runs this weekend
and next, February 17, 18, 19,
24, 25 and 26. Curtain call is
eight o'clock on all six nights.
Tickets are $4 for students and $6
for the general public, and are
available in advance from production members and during
weekdays outside Levering
Cafeteria.

Welch lecture, is not a matter of
medicine but a matter of ethics.
Dr. Wallach, chairman of the
